Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Biomanufacturing of Advanced Porous Carbon Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project deals with the development of porous carbon materials made from fungal-derived precursors. The demand for porous carbon materials, like activated carbon (AC), is expected to surpass supply capabilities by 2020. Since AC is used in applications such as water filtration, air purification, and energy storage, it is imperative to develop new and higher performing versions of AC. This new technology takes advantage of sustainable carbon sources present in wastewater, such as municipal and industrial, to grow tunable biotemplates for AC which have the potential to outperform traditional AC. By treating wastewater during manufacturing, marginal cost is reduced and production occurs near end consumers.

This NSF I-Corps project will help determine a potential product-market fit for fungal derived activated carbons. This is a platform technology using filamentous fungus to capture renewable and sustainable carbon from wastewater as a base for a variety of synthetic carbons. Organic carbon, present in wastewater, provide a nutrient source for potential cost savings and large scale production. By taking advantage of facile and rapid fungal growth, and controlling the carbonization conditions, it may be possible to produce commercial carbons at a fraction of the cost of current products. Tunability in the growth stage unlocks a series of advantageous product developments such as microstructure, dopants, and chemistry. The main advantages of the newly derived activated carbon include monolithic structures, nano-metal integration, high surface area, high purity, potential for renewable labeling, and low production cost.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF I-Corp Teams Project successfully instructed four academic researchers and industry members on the techniques of customer discovery and development of a business model canvas. These techniques were applied to a materials technology of biosynthetically derived carbon materials developed at the University of Colorado Boulder.

The 8-week intensive program had the four-member team perform 100 interviews with potential customers, related parties, and end-users in the fields of water filtration and brewery wastewater treatment. True pain points were identified and a product-market fit was formed for the carbon technology. Strategic partners were also identified who can aid in execution of the final business model.

The final outcome led to a “go” decision by the team, formation of the startup Emergy LLC, an exclusive option agreement with the University of Colorado Boulder to further develop R&D on the technology, and submission of a NSF SBIR proposal disseminating the results in the form of a commercialization plan.

The broader impacts of this short project include the decision to pursue a societal improving technology. Biosynthetically derived carbons have negative CO2 scores – being derived from waste and needing minimal processing. They are aimed at supplanting traditional carbons with high CO2 scores that are conventionally derived from unsustainable sources of coal, wood, and coconut. While many academic studies are published on more theoretically sustainable materials, the NSF I-Corp Teams Program has provided a well-structured path for commercialization of a deployment ready material.

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2017
Modified by: Se-Hee Lee
